item.title: Pros and Cons of Outsourcing
item.description:
Abstract

Pakistani businesses now use outsourcing to help them reduce costs and operate better. Companies need to use it the most in the IT industries and production industries. Businesses face two key problems when they rely on external vendors â€“ they need outside help to keep operations going and cannot control product quality. This research article uses examples from the textile, manufacturing, and IT industries to examine both positive and negative outsourcing aspects in Pakistani markets. The research combines secondary data sources with specific case examples to examine both how outsourcing influences business efficiency and market structure today. The research demonstrates outsourcing creates competitive benefits but needs proper management to succeed despite issues with unreliable quality and cultural confusion.

item.title: The Geater City of Jhang: A Legacy of Punjab
item.description: Jhang, often perceived today as a modest town near Faisalabad, carries a rich historical legacy that contrasts its current image. Ironically, Faisalabad itself was once just a Tehsil of Jhang. Known for its deep cultural roots, Jhang is situated between two major rivers, the Jhelum and Chenab, which not only enhance its geographical importance but also contribute to its long-standing historical significance. In fact, Jhang is often regarded as the geographical center of Pakistan. In fact, much of the long-distance travels took place via Jhang before the motorways were a thing.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of Marxism in Pakistan and South Asia
item.description:
Abstract:

In the mid-20th century, South Asia embraced Marxism as a political movement that supported proletarian class warfare campaigned to eliminate capitalism with an anti-bourgeoise stance. Marxism found its strongest reception among three major South Asian countries specifically Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh because social and economic imbalances created favorable conditions. This investigation focuses on how Marxism developed across the region while studying both its formation reasons and its contribution to political transformations and its eventual decline. According to the study, Marxism introduced reforms for workers and land distribution yet collapsed because of inner disagreements alongside state crackdowns together with the worldwide weakening of communist ideas.
